Items.Title: Roll Call
Invocation
Items.AgendaNote:
Delivered by: Bishop Mitchell G. Taylor, Pastor, Center of Hope International, 12-11 40th Avenue, Long Island City, NY 11101.

Motion to spread the invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Gioia.
Items.MinutesNote:
The Invocation was delivered by: Bishop Mitchell G. Taylor, Pastor, Center of Hope International, 12-11 40th Avenue, Long Island City, N.Y. 11101.

Council Member Gioia moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Items.Title: Adoption of Minutes
Items.AgendaNote: Motion that the Minutes of the Stated Meetings March 26 and March 31, 2008 be adopted as printed by Council Member Mendez.
Items.MinutesNote: Council Member Mendez moved that the Minutes of the Stated Meeting of March 26, 2008 and the Recessed Council Meeting of March 31, 2008 be adopted as printed.

Items.Title: Petitions and Communications
Land Use Call-Ups

By The Speaker (Council Member Quinn):
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(b) of the Council and Section 20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Consumer Affairs approving an unenclosed sidewalk café located at 225 West 12th Street Community Board 2, Application 20085221 TCM shall be subject to review by the Council.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, Twelfth Street Corp. d.b.a. Village Den., Manhattan (20085221TCM)

Items.Title:
By Council Member Palma:
Pursuant to Rule 11.20(b) of the Council and Section 20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code, the Council resolves that the action of the Department of Consumer Affairs approving an enclosed sidewalk café located at 1161 Castle Hill Avenue Community Board 9, Application 20075306 TCX shall be subject to review by the Council.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Call-Up be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, 1161 castle Hill Avenue, Bronx (20075306TCX)

Items.Title: Communication from the Speaker
Discussion of General Orders
Reports of Special Committees
Reports of Standing Committees
Resolution declaring May 15, 2008, as “Huntington’s Disease Awareness Day” in the City of New York.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Health
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Declaring May 15, 2008, as “Huntington’s Disease Awareness Day” in the City of New York.

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Mangement
A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to electronic equipment collection standards.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Introduction be Overridden by Council approved by Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Electronic equipment collection standards.

Items.Title: Communication from the Mayor - Mayors veto and disapproval message of Introductory Number 729, in relation to electronic equipment collection standards.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Mayor's Message be Filed by Council approved by consent Roll Call.

Items.Title: Report of the Committee on Transportation

A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to modifying department of transportation performance measures in an effort to help reduce traffic congestion and promote high performance modes citywide.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Introduction be Approved by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Modifying department of transportation performance targets and indicators  towards the goal of reducing traffic congestion citywide.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the President, the U.S. Congress and the U.S. Department of Defense to rescind the current “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell, Don’t Pursue” policy and allow lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgendered persons to serve openly in the military.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Veterans
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 3 Council Members formally voted against this item: 
Council Members Felder, Ignizio, and Oddo.

The following Council Member formally abstained to vote on this item: 
Council Member Vallone. Jr.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Rescind the current “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell, Don’t Pursue” policy and allow lesbian, gay and bisexual persons to serve openly in the military.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Congress to pass the Summer Jobs Stimulus Act of 2008.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Youth Services
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing no objections, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

Adopted unanimously by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Approved, by Council
Items.MatterName: Congress to pass the Summer Jobs Stimulus Act of 2008.

Discussion of Resolutions

INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS

Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to enact S.6724/A.9695, which provides an opportunity for a one-year moratorium on a mortgage foreclosure and gives at-risk homeowners a chance to work with lenders to find fair and equitable ways to restructure their loans and protect their homes.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer Affairs
Items.MatterName: One-year moratorium on a mortgage foreclosure and gives at-risk homeowners a chance to work with lenders to find fair and equitable ways to restructure their loans and protect their homes.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Workers Compensation Board to establish a claim review panel for 9/11-related workers compensation claim applications at the New York City Law Department.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Service and Labor
Items.MatterName: NYS Workers Compensation Board to establish a claim review panel for 9/11-related workers compensation claim applications at the NYC Law Department.

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Stavisky, S. 5971-A, and Assembly Member Hevesi, A. 8381-A, “AN ACT to allow Thomas Steier to be reclassified as a Tier II member of the New York city retirement system”.
Items.ActionText: This SLR was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Thomas Steier, reclassified as Tier II (S.5971-A/A.8381-A)

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Lanza, S. 7517-A, and Assembly Member Abbate, A. 10506, “AN ACT to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to providing interest in certain benefits payable by the police and fire variable supplements funds to pension fund beneficiaries”.
Items.ActionText: This SLR was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Variable Supplements Fund (S.7517-A/A. 10506)

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Maltese, S. 2797-B, and Assembly Member Seminerio, A. 4974-B, “AN ACT to amend the retirement and social security law, in relation to the determination of benefits of correction members of the New York city employees’ retirement system”.
Items.ActionText: This SLR was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Correction members benefits of NYCERS (S. 2797-B/A. 4974-B)

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Maltese, S. 4410-A, and Assembly Members Abbate and Carrozza, A. 7384-A, “AN ACT to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the crediting of prior service by the police pension fund of such city”.
Items.ActionText: This SLR was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Crediting prior service (S.4410-A/A. 7384-A)

Items.Title: State Legislation Resolution requesting the New York State Legislature to pass bills introduced by Senator Lanza, S. 6811, and Assembly Member Kavanagh, A. 10071, “AN ACT to amend the vehicle and traffic law, in relation to authorizing a city with a population of one million or more to make the obstruction of traffic intersections a parking violation”.
Items.ActionText: This SLR was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on State and Federal Legislation
Items.MatterName: Blocking the box fine (S.6811/A.10071)

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Department of State to promulgate standards and rules concerning the sanitization of mattresses that include requirements sufficient to eradicate bedbugs in reconditioned mattresses before their sale.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer Affairs
Items.MatterName: Promulgate standards and rules concerning the sanitization of mattresses that include requirements sufficient to eradicate bedbugs in reconditioned mattresses before their sale.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Administration for Children’s Services to achieve stated goals herein including the creation of (i) a written procedure to be followed before closing centers; (ii) a searchable database for locating centers on the website; (iii) a centralized city waiting list; (iv) a system for reevaluating enrollment and capacity numbers; and (v) a report detailing monthly attendance and enrollment figures citywide for subsidized childcare for the last two calendar years and to report such achievements to the Council by July 1, 2008 before implementing Project Full Enrollment Initiative.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on General Welfare
Items.MatterName: Administration for Children’s Services to achieve stated goals.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to increasing the wattage of electric lighting fixtures in certain public parts of multiple dwellings.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Increasing the wattage of electric lighting fixtures in certain public parts of multiple dwellings.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York City Department of Education to test all schools constructed or renovated before 1978 to ascertain the levels of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs).
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection
Items.MatterName: Dept of Education to test all schools constructed or renovated before 1978 to ascertain the levels of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs).

Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use
Items.MatterName: Performance design criteria for illuminated signs.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to defining First-Amendment protected material for the purposes of general vending.

Items.MatterName: Defining First-Amendment protected material for the purposes of general vending.

Items.MatterName: Requiring that vendors pass a written exam.

Items.MatterName: Food vendor permits for pre-packaged food and drinks.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to amend the Vehicle and Traffic Law to allow New York City to operate additional red light traffic cameras so that more cameras are available to cover intersections where there are a high number of traffic accidents.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Vehicle and Traffic Law to allow NYC to operate additional red light traffic cameras so that more cameras are available to cover intersections where there are a high number of traffic accidents.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Mayor of the City of New York to declare a state of emergency with respect to the HIV/AIDS crisis in the black MSM community in New York City, and urging the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene to take necessary actions to address such health emergency.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Declare a state of emergency with respect to the HIV/AIDS crisis in the black MSM community in NYC.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to authorizing the department of transportation to extend the expiration date of the operating authority of certain unsubsidized private bus services.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use
Items.MatterName: Authorizing the department of transportation to extend the expiration date of the operating authority of certain unsubsidized private bus services.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the New York City Police Department to make certain domestic violence statistics available through its website.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Requiring the NYPD to make certain domestic violence statistics available through its website.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Bloomberg Administration to place a moratorium on the implementation of the Project Full Enrollment Initiative.

Items.MatterName: The Bloomberg Administration to place a moratorium on the implementation of the Project Full Enrollment Initiative.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the submission of quarterly reports by the New York City Police Department detailing the number of summonses issued to trucks for traffic infractions.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Assembly to pass A.0305, which would amend the New York State Penal Law to include the financial exploitation of the elderly or disabled within the crime of larceny.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Amend the NYS Penal Law to include the financial exploitation of the elderly or disabled within the crime of larceny.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Legislature to amend the Criminal Procedure Law, by adding the advanced age of a witness as a ground for an order directing the conditional examination of that witness.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Amend the Criminal Procedure Law, by adding the advanced age of a witness as a ground for an order directing the conditional examination of that witness.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the New York State Assembly to pass A.3640-A, which would amend the Criminal Procedure Law to allow the submission of business records by affidavit without the need for live testimony by the custodian of records in grand jury proceedings.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Amend the Criminal Procedure Law to allow the submission of business records by affidavit without the need for live testimony by the custodian of records in grand jury proceedings.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the State Legislature to amend the Hudson River Park Act to authorize a marine transfer station and environmental education center in the Gansevoort peninsula in lower Manhattan through the passage of Senate bill S. 5988 and Assembly bill A.9005.
Items.AgendaNote: Preconsidered - Adopted by the Committee on Sanitation and Solid Waste Management
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the Public Advocate (Ms. Gotbaum) declared the Resolution to be adopted.

The following 3 Council Members formally voted against this item: 
Council Members Brewer, Gerson, and Lappin.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Approved, by Council
Items.MatterName: Hudson River Park Act to authorize a marine transfer station and environmental education center in the Gansevoort peninsula in lower Manhattan through the passage of S.5988/A.9005.

Items.Title: Application no. C 070577 ZSM submitted by MCP SO Strategic 56, LP pursuant to Section 197-c and 201 of the New York City Charter for the grant of a special permit pursuant to Sections 13-562 and 74-52 of the Zoning Resolution to allow an attended public parking garage with a maximum capacity of 76 spaces on portions of the ground floor, cellar and subceller of a proposed mixed use development on property located at 31-37 West 56th street (Block 1272, Lot 14, 15 16, 17 and 18), within the Special Midtown District, Borough of Manhattan, Community District 5.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Application be Approved, by Council approved by consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Zoning Reso., 31-37 West 56th Street , Manhattan (C070577ZSM)

Items.MinutesNote: At this point the Speaker (Council Member Quinn) made the following annoucements:

Whereupon on motion of the Speaker (Council Member Quinn), the Clerk of the Council adjourned to meet again on Wednesday, May 28,  2008.

HECTOR L. DIAZ, City Clerk
Clerk of the Council
The presence of a quorum was announced by The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera).
The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera)
The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such motion which was decided in the affirmative by the following vote:

At this point, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) declared that the aforementioned items were adopted and referred to the Committee on Land Use and to the appropriate Land Use Subcommittee.

Items.Title: Application no. 20075306 TCX, pursuant to §20-226 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, concerning the petition of Sports Plus Café Inc., to establish, maintain and operate an enclosed sidewalk café at 1161 castle Hill Avenue, Borough of the Bronx, Council District no. 18.  This application is subject to review and action by the Land Use Committee only if called-up by vote of the Council pursuant to Rule 11.20b of the Council and §20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code.
Items.ActionText: This Land Use Application was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Land Use
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk Cafe, 1161 castle Hill Avenue, Bronx (20075306TCX)

Items.Title: Application no. 20085221 TCM, pursuant to §20-226 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, concerning the petition of Twelfth Street Corp. d.b.a. Village Den., to continue, maintain and operate an unenclosed sidewalk café at 225 West 12th Street, Borough of Manhattan, Council District no. 3.  This application is subject to review and action by the Land Use Committee only if called-up by vote of the Council pursuant to Rule 11.20b of the Council and §20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code.

Items.MinutesNote: The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Rivera) put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such reports, which were decided in the affirmative by the following vote:

The following files were removed from the General Order Calendar and voted separately:

Int No. 729  45-3-0 (override vote)

See files for individual votes.


Notwithstanding the objection of the Mayor, Int No. 729 was enacted into law by the Council upon the Override of the Mayor's Veto by the vote of 45-3-0.
